revision.text:
{{About|Van Gogh's paintings|the story by Alphonse Daudet|L'Arlésienne (novel and play)|the work by Bizet|L'Arlésienne (Bizet)|films derived from them|L'Arlésienne (film)}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = LArlesienneWithGlovesAndUmbrella.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = L'Arlésienne | alt = | other_language_1 = also known as | other_title_1 = Portrait of Madame Ginoux | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Vincent van Gogh]] | year = 1888 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 92.5 | width_metric = 73.5 | height_imperial = 36.4 | width_imperial = 28.9 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = Paris | museum = [[Musée d'Orsay]] }} '''''L'Arlésienne''''', '''''L'Arlésienne: Madame Ginoux''''', or '''''Portrait of Madame Ginoux''''' is the title given to a group of six similar [[painting]]s by [[Vincent van Gogh]], painted in [[Arles]], November 1888 (or later), and in [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence|Saint-Rémy]], February 1890. '''L'Arlésienne''' is pronounced 'lar lay zyen'; it means literally "the woman from Arles". The subject, ''Marie Jullian'' (or ''Julien''), was born in [[Arles]] June 8, 1848 and died there August 2, 1911. She married ''Joseph-Michel Ginoux'' in 1866 and together they ran the ''Café de la Gare'', 30 Place Lamartine, where van Gogh lodged from May to mid-September 1888. He had the [[Yellow House (painting)|Yellow House]] in Arles furnished to settle there. Evidently until this time, van Gogh's relations to M. and Mme. Ginoux had remained more or less commercial (the café is the subject of ''[[The Night Café]]''), but [[Paul Gauguin|Gauguin]]'s arrival in Arles altered the situation. His courtship charmed the lady, then about 40 years of age, and in the first few days of November 1888 Madame Ginoux agreed to have a portrait session for Gauguin, and his friend van Gogh. Within an hour, Gauguin produced a charcoal drawing while Vincent produced a full-scale painting, "knocked off in ''one'' hour".{{cite web|title=To Theo van Gogh. Arles, on or about Saturday, 3 November 1888|url=http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let717/letter.html|work=Vincent van Gogh: The Letters|publisher=''[[Van Gogh Museum|Vincent van Gogh Museum]]''|accessdate=9 February 2012}} ==November 1888 version and its ''repetition''== Van Gogh's first version, now in the [[Musée d'Orsay]], Paris, is painted on [[Hessian (cloth)|burlap]]. A complete ''piece'' of this fabric was acquired by Gauguin just after his arrival in Arles, and used by both artists in November and December 1888.Letter; see Druick & Seghers Image:LArlesienneWithGlovesAndUmbrella.jpg|''L'Arlésienne'': Madame Ginoux with gloves and umbrella. Oil on canvas (burlap), 92.5 x 73.5 cm, Musée d'Orsay, Paris Image:LArlesienneWithBooks.jpg|''L'Arlésienne'': Madame Ginoux with books. Oil on canvas, 91.5 x 73.7 cm, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York For the second version, now in the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in [[New York City]], van Gogh again painted on the commercially pre-primed canvas he had previously used, and he replaced the gloves and umbrella with some books. ==February 1890 versions== While in the asylum at [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence|Saint-Rémy]], van Gogh painted another five portraits of Madame Ginoux, based on Gauguin's charcoal drawing of November 1888. Of these, one was intended for Gauguin, one for his brother [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], one for himself and one for Madame Ginoux. The provenance of the version in the [[Kröller-Müller Museum]] is not known in detail, but the painting is known to have been previously owned by [[Albert Aurier]], an early champion of Vincent's paintings.Aurier, G. Albert. "[http://www.vggallery.com/misc/archives/aurier.htm The Isolated Ones: Vincent van Gogh]", January, 1890. Reproduced on vggallery.com. Retrieved 25 June 2009. The version intended for Madame Ginoux was lost and has not been recovered. This is the version Vincent was delivering to Madame Ginoux in Arles when he suffered his relapse on February 22, 1890.{{cite book|last=Hulsker|first=Jan|title=The Complete Van Gogh|year=1985|publisher=Crescent|isbn=0-517-44867-X|page=440}} In an unfinished letter to Gauguin that was never sent, Vincent remarked that working on her portrait cost him another month of illness.{{cite web|title=To Paul Gauguin, Auvers-sur-Oise, on or about Tuesday, 17 June 1890|url=http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/RM23/letter.html|work=Vincent van Gogh: The Letters|publisher=''[[Van Gogh Museum]]''|accessdate=9 February 2012}} Gauguin's version was the one with a pink background, currently in the São Paulo Museum of Art. Gauguin was enthusiastic about the portrait, writing:
I've seen the canvas of Madame Ginoux. Very fine and very curious, I like it better than my drawing. Despite your ailing state you have never worked with so much ''balance'' while conserving the sensation and the interior warmth needed for a ''work of art'', precisely in an era when art is a business regulated in advance by cold calculations.{{cite web|title=Paul Gauguin to Vincent van Gogh. Paris, on or about Friday, 13 June 1890|url=http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let884/letter.html#n-2|work=Vincent van Gogh: The Letters|publisher=''[[Van Gogh Museum]]''|accessdate=12 February 2012}}
In a letter to his sister [[Wil van Gogh|Wil]], dated 5 June 1890, Vincent set out his philosophy for doing portraits: "I should like to do portraits which will appear as revelations to people in a hundred years' time. In other words I am not trying to achieve this by photographic likeness but by rendering our impassioned expressions, by using our modern knowledge and appreciation of colour as a means of rendering and exalting character ... The portrait of the Arlésienne has a colourless and matt flesh tone, the eyes are calm and very simple, the clothing is black, the background pink, and she is leaning on a green table with green books. But in the copy that Theo has, the clothing is pink, the background yellowy-white, and the front of the open bodice is muslin in a white that merges into green. Among all these light colours, only the hair, the eyelashes and the eyes form black patches."{{cite book|last=Pomerans|first=Arnold|title=The Letters of Vincent Van Gogh|year=1996|publisher=[[Penguin Group|The Penguin Press]]|isbn=0-14-044674-5|url=http://us.penguingroup.com/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780140446746,00.html|page=492}}{{cite web|title=To Willemien van Gogh. Auvers-sur-Oise, Thursday, 5 June 1890|url=http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let879/letter.html|work=Vincent van Gogh: The Letters|publisher=''[[Van Gogh Museum]]''|accessdate=11 February 2012}} File:L'Arlésienne (portret van Madame Ginoux).jpg|''L'Arlésienne'', [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], Otterlo File:Vincent van Gogh - L'Arlesienne (Madame Ginoux).jpg|''L'Arlésienne'', [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna]], Rome Image:Van Gogh - A Arlesiana.jpg|''L'Arlésienne'', [[São Paulo Museum of Art]] Image:LArlesienne Madame Ginoux4.jpg|''L'Arlésienne'', private collection On 2 May 2006, the painting with the floral background sold at auction at [[Christie's]], New York, for more than $40{{nbsp}}million (USD).{{cite news|last=Carol|first=Vogel|title=A Famous Face, and Now an Auction Star|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/03/arts/design/03auction.html|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=3 May 2006}} This was the version that Vincent gave to Theo.{{cite web|title=Sale 1655 / Lot 19|url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=4701806|work=L'Arlésienne, Madame Ginoux|publisher=''[[Christie's]]''|accessdate=9 February 2012}} ==Gauguin's versions== Gauguin produced a charcoal sketch at the original sitting of Madame Ginoux in November 1888, and later produced a canvas. Image:Gauguin Ginoux Sketch.jpg|''Portrait of Madame Ginoux'', Image:Paul Gauguin 072.jpg|''Night Café'', ==''The Arena''== Members of [[The Roulin Family (Van Gogh series)|the Roulin Family]] are depicted in this portrait,for example, Arnold, Wilfred N. ''Vincent van Gogh: Chemicals, Crises, and Creativity,'' Birkhãuser, Boston, 1992. {{ISBN|0-8176-3616-1}}. p. 253. and the woman in Arlésienne costume has the profile of Madame Ginoux. [[File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 028.jpg|thumb|[[Vincent van Gogh]], ''[[Les Arènes]]''
(December 1888)
[[Hermitage Museum]], St. Petersburg]] Gayford, Martin. ''The Yellow House: Van Gogh, Gauguin, and Nine Turbulent Weeks in Arles'', Fig Tree, Penguin, 2006, {{ISBN|0-670-91497-5}}. p. 152. == References in culture == In the book ''[[Lolita]]'', by [[Vladimir Nabokov]], the narrator calls ''L'Arlésienne'' "that banal darling of the arty middle class". ==Resources== ===Pedigrees=== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Portraits of Madame Ginoux (Van Gogh)}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4967738.stm BBC news story of May 2006 auction] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/167899 ''Van Gogh, paintings and drawings: a special loan exhibition''], a fully digitized exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries, which contains material on this painting (see index) {{Vincent van Gogh}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arlesienne}} [[Category:Vincent van Gogh paintings of Arles]] [[Category:1888 paintings]] [[Category:1890 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Musée d'Orsay]] [[Category:Paintings of the Museum of Modern Art (New York)]] [[Category:Portraits of women]] [[Category:Books in art]]

{{about||the Inside No. 9 episode|Last Gasp (Inside No. 9)}} {{Infobox publisher | image = [[Image:Last Gasp.gif|150px]] | parent = | status = | founded = {{Start date and age|1970| | }} in [[Berkeley, California]] | founder = [[Ron Turner (publisher)|Ron Turner]][http://comics.lib.msu.edu/rri/trri/turner_n.htm Ron Turner at Michigan State University Libraries] | successor = | country = | headquarters = [[San Francisco, California]] | distribution = SCB Distributors{{Cite web| title = The 2016 Book Distributors Profiles - Publishing Trends| accessdate = 2017-12-25| url = http://www.publishingtrends.com/2016/10/6788/}} | keypeople = Colin TurnerLepage, Cécile. [http://www.sfbg.com/pixel_vision/2010/03/30/40-year-last-gasp-thats-getting-stronger "A 40-year Last Gasp that's getting stronger,"] ''San Francisco Bay Guardian'' online (March 30, 2010). | publications = [[Book]]s, [[Graphic novels]], [[Comics]] | topics =[[Rock music]], [[Art]], [[Poetry]] | genre = [[Underground comix]] | imprints = Hell Comics
Cocoanut Comics
Priaprism Press
Sexploitation Comics Group | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|http://www.lastgasp.com}} }} '''Last Gasp''' is a [[San Francisco]]-based "[http://www.lastgasp.com/faq/ F A Q]." Last Gasp Books. Retrieved on July 30, 2012. "Last Gasp 777 Florida Street San Francisco, CA 94110" [[book publisher]] with a [[lowbrow art]] and [[counterculture]] focus.[http://www.thewavemag.com/pagegen.php?articleid=23593&pagename=article "Last Gasp Hero" ''The Wave Magazine''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061112224401/http://www.thewavemag.com/pagegen.php?pagename=article&articleid=23593 |date=2006-11-12 }} Owned and operated by [[Ron Turner (publisher)|Ron Turner]], for most of its existence Last Gasp was a publisher, [[direct market|distributor]], and wholesaler of [[underground comix]][http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/04/29/LVGIPPG7M51.DTL&hw=ron+turner&sn=001&sc=1000 "On the Town: with Ron Turner" SF Chronicle, April 29, 2007] and books of all types. Last Gasp was established in 1970. Although the company came onto the scene a bit later than some of the other underground publishers, Last Gasp continued publishing comix far longer most of its competitors. In addition to publishing notable original titles like ''[[Slow Death]]'', ''[[Wimmen's Comix]]'', ''[[Binky Brown Meets the Holy Virgin Mary]]'', and ''[[Weirdo (magazine)|Weirdo]]'', it also picked up the publishing reins of important titles — such as ''[[Zap Comix]]'' and ''[[Young Lust (comics)|Young Lust]]'' — from rivals that had gone out of business. Last Gasp no longer publishes "floppy" comics; the company publishes art and photography books, [[graphic novel]]s, fiction, and poetry, producing 10-15 new titles per year. == History == [[Image:Ron Turner (San Francisco 2007).jpg|thumb|right|Ron Turner in 2007.]] '''Last Gasp Eco Funnies''' was founded in [[Berkeley, California]], in [[1970 in comics|1970]] by [[San Francisco State University]] graduate studentNelson, Gayle. [http://www.lastgasp.com/olg/ "The Origins of Last Gasp,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214192729/http://www.lastgasp.com/olg/ |date=2013-12-14 }} Last Gasp website (Jan. 1999). Accessed Dec. 14, 2013. Ronald E. Turner,[http://files1.comics.org/img/gcd/generic_images/3/3055.jpg Indicia], ''Slow Death'' #8 (1977).''R. Crumb: Conversations'' by Robert Crumb & D. K. Holm. University Press of Mississippi, 2004 {{ISBN|978-1-57806-637-7}} (p. 93)''A history of underground comics'', Mark James Estren. Ronin Publishing, 1992 {{ISBN|978-0-914171-64-5}} (p. 254) with the help of [[Gary Arlington]], to publish the ecologically-themed comics title ''[[Slow Death Funnies]]'' (in conjunction with the first [[Earth Day]]). Last Gasp followed ''Slow Death Funnies'' with the all-female anthology [[It Ain't Me, Babe (comics)|''It Ain't Me, Babe'']], spearheaded by [[Trina Robbins]]. Last Gasp incorporated on September 11, 1971.Levin, Bob.[https://books.google.com/books?id=UMB7DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122&dq=Last+Gasp+Visual+Yoyo+Tribe&source=bl&ots=DiqAeCaRep&sig=Vzg6zY5h9-HFVCf9FvbUXPQmdv8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO8NPItMTRAhXBQCYKHTiXDSMQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=Last%20Gasp%20Visual%20Yoyo%20Tribe&f=false ''The Pirates and the Mouse: Disney's War Against The Underground''] (Fantagraphics, 2003), p. 123. In the time period 1971–1973, Last Gasp published ''[[Air Pirates Funnies]]'' #1–2 and a number of other [[Air Pirates]]-related titles, including ''The Tortoise and the Hare'', ''Dopin' Dan'' #1–3, and ''Merton of the Movement''. (Turner insists that he only served as an advisor to the Air Pirates collective, despite them crediting his company as "publisher.") Considered to be an "enabler" of the Air Pirates infamous [[Walt Disney]] parodies, Turner's name was added to Disney's lawsuit against the collective. Turner quickly settled with Disney, but Air Pirates [[Dan O'Neill]], [[Bobby London]], and [[Ted Richards]] continued fighting, in a case that dragged on for years.{{cite book|author=Tom Sito|authorlink=Tom Sito|title=Drawing the Line: The Untold Story of the Animation Unions from Bosko to Bart Simpson|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XZ0PsCWPSZ0C|date=October 6, 2006|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=0-8131-7148-2|pages=236–37}} The company's success with ''Slow Death'' and ''It Ain't Me, Babe'' enabled Last Gasp to expand into distribution, in addition to publishing. The company soon became a major part of the [[underground comix]] movement. Sociopolitical themes were explored in Last Gasp series such as [[Guy Colwell]]'s ''[[Inner City Romance]]'' (1972–1979), which portrayed gritty urban tales; ''[[Armageddon (underground comic)|Armageddon]]'' (1973), which focused on [[anarcho-capitalism]];[https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0O-Jh5dugUC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=barney+steel+libertarian+comic&source=bl&ots=r7epOpcCak&sig=dsmDftLoNXkgoaYv9v5EJmRaCBk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=U-KWVPmfEpe5oQTy5YKAAw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=barney%20steel%20libertarian%20comic&f=false Multicultural Comics: From Zap to Blue Beetle] - Race and Comix by Leonard Rifas pp. 33-34 and ''[[Anarchy Comics]]'' (1978), which focused on [[left-wing politics]]. In addition to publishing ''[[Wimmen's Comix]]'' for much of its run, Last Gasp published a number of other comix with feminist themes, including ''[[It Ain't Me, Babe (comics)|It Ain't Me, Babe]]'', ''[[Tits & Clits Comix]]'', ''[[Twisted Sisters (comic)|Twisted Sisters]]'' #1, and ''[[Good Girls (comics)|Good Girls]]''. In 1972, Last Gasp published [[Justin Green (cartoonist)|Justin Green]]'s seminal autobiographical comic ''[[Binky Brown Meets the Holy Virgin Mary]]''. Beginning in 1972, Last Gasp began publishing ongoing titles moving over from other companies; beginning with ''[[Young Lust (comics)|Young Lust]]'', and then [[Rand Holmes]]' ''[[Harold Hedd]]''. In 1977, the company picked up [[Joyce Farmer]] and [[Lyn Chevely]]'s ''[[Tits & Clits Comix]]'', publishing that series until 1987. Last Gasp published the final three issues of ''[[San Francisco Comic Book]]'' in 1980–1983, and the latter half of ''[[Zap Comix]]''' run from 1982–2005. Last Gasp also published ''[[Weirdo (magazine)|Weirdo]]'' from 1981–1993, and ''[[Cherry Poptart]]'' from 1982–1992. In the early 1980s Last Gasp published some of the first books about the West Coast [[punk rock]] scene, including a number of titles by [[Peter Belsito]]. Last Gasp moved its headquarters from Berkeley to San Francisco in c. 1975.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Starting in 1975, Ron Turner began hosting the annual "Burritos, Beer & Cheer" holiday party at the Last Gasp offices, which was also a fundraiser for the [[Martin de Porres|Martin de Porres House of Hospitality]], a free soup kitchen located in San Francisco. Last Gasp hosted "Burritos, Beer & Cheer" for more than 30 years.Beale, Scott. [http://laughingsquid.com/last-gasp-holiday-party-photos/ "Last Gasp Holiday Party 2005,"] LaughingSquid.com (Dec. 17, 2005). In the period 2004-2010, Last Gasp published English-language compilations of popular [[manga]] titles, including [[Fumiyo Kouno]]'s ''[[Town of Evening Calm, Country of Cherry Blossoms]]''; [[Junko Mizuno]]'s ''[[Pure Trance]]''; and [[Keiji Nakazawa]]'s ''[[Barefoot Gen]]''. In early December 2016, Last Gasp announced it was ending its distribution business to focus solely on book publishing. (As one of the last independent distributors, they handled comics from more than 100 small comics publishers.) As a consequence, the company planned to lay off the bulk of its dozen employees by February 2017.Aoki, Deb. [http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/72221-last-gasp-shuts-down-its-distribution-operation.html "Comics Publisher Last Gasp Shuts Down its Distribution Operation,"] ''Publishers Weekly'' (Dec 07, 2016). == Creators associated with Last Gasp == Notable artists published by Last Gasp include [[Tim Biskup]], [[Robert Crumb]], [[Richard Corben]], [[Ron English (artist)|Ron English]], [[Camille Rose Garcia]], [[Justin Green (cartoonist)|Justin Green]], [[Bill Griffith]], John Howard, [[Greg Irons]], [[Shawna Kenney]], [[Spain Rodriguez]], [[Mark Ryden]], [[Dori Seda]], [[Larry Welz]], [[Robert Williams (artist)|Robert Williams]], and [[S. Clay Wilson]]. == Titles published (selected) == ===Comix === {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * ''[[Rand Holmes|The Adventures of Harold Hedd]]'' (1972–Sept. 1973) * ''[[Anarchy Comics]]'' (4 issues; 1978–1987) * ''[[Armageddon (underground comic)|Armageddon]]'' (3 issues; 1970–1973) * ''[[Binky Brown Meets the Holy Virgin Mary]]'' (1972) * ''[[Rick Shubb|Brain Fantasy]]'' (2 issues; May 1972–Jan. 1975) * ''[[Cherry (comics)|Cherry Poptart]]'' (13 issues; 1982–1992) * ''[[From A to Z, in the Chocolate Alphabet|Harlan Ellison's Chocolate Alphabet]]'' (Aug. 1975) * ''[[Cocaine Comix]]'' (4 issues; 1975–1982) * ''[[Dirty Laundry (comic)|Dirty Laundry]]'' (1974, 1978, 1993) * ''[[Ted Richards (artist)|Dopin' Dan]]'' (3 issues; 1972–1979) * ''[[Larry Todd|Dr. Atomic]]'' (6 issues; Sept. 1972–Apr. 1981) * ''[[Melinda Gebbie|Fresca Zizis]]'' (1977) * ''[[Good Girls (comics)|Good Girls]]'' (6 issues; 1987–1991) * ''[[Grim Wit]]'' (2 issues; June–Sept. 1973) * ''[[Harold Hedd]]'' (3 issues, 1973–1984) * ''[[Horny Biker Slut]]'' (13 issues; 1990–1998) * ''[[Hup (comics)|Hup]]'' (4 issues; 1986–1992) * ''[[Guy Colwell|Inner City Romance]]'' (5 issues; 1972–1978) * ''[[It Ain't Me, Babe (comics)|It Ain't Me, Babe]]'' (July 1970) * ''[[Last Gasp Comix & Stories]]'' (5 issues; 1994–1997) * ''The Legion of Charlies'' (Fall 1971) — one-shot by [[Tom Veitch]], [[Greg Irons]], and [[Dave Sheridan (cartoonist)|Dave Sheridan]] * ''[[Mickey Rat]]'' (2 issues; 1980–1982) * ''[[George DiCaprio|Neurocomics]]'' (Mar. 1979) * ''Skull'' (5 issues; 1970–1972) * ''[[Slow Death Funnies]]/Slow Death'' (11 issues; 1970–1992) * ''Tales from the Leather Nun'' (1973) * ''[[Twisted Sisters (comic)|Twisted Sisters]]'' #1 (1976) * ''[[Weirdo (magazine)|Weirdo]]'' (28 issues; Spring 1981–Summer 1993) * ''[[Wimmen's Comix]]'' (10 issues; Spring 1981–Summer 1993) * ''[[Young Lust (comics)|Young Lust]]'' (5 issues; 1972, 1987–1993) * ''[[Zap Comix]]'' (16 issues; 1982–2005) }} === Manga translations === * [[Fumiyo Kouno|Kouno, Fumiyo]]. ''[[Town of Evening Calm, Country of Cherry Blossoms]]'' (2004) * [[Junko Mizuno|Mizuno, Junko]]. ''[[Pure Trance]]'' (2005) * [[Keiji Nakazawa|Nakazawa, Keiji]]. ''[[Barefoot Gen]]'' (10 issues, 2004–2010) === Books === * Belsito, Peter, Bob Davis, and Marian Kester. ''[[StreetArt: The Punk Poster in San Francisco 1977-1981]]'' (1981) {{ISBN|9780867193008}} * Belsito, Peter and Bob Davis. ''Hardcore California: A History of Punk and New Wave'' (1983) {{ISBN|9780867193145}} * Belsito, Peter. ''Notes From the Pop Underground'' (1985) {{ISBN|978-0867193374}} * [[Joani Blank|Blank, Joani]] (ed.) ''[[Femalia]]'' (2nd ed., 2011) * [[Cometbus]]. ''[[Cometbus|Despite Everything: A Cometbus Omnibus]]'' (2002) {{ISBN|0-86719-561-4}} * [[Tee Corinne|Corinne, Tee]]. ''The Cunt Coloring Book'' (1989) * [[Bill Griffith|Griffith, Bill]]. ''[[Zippy the Pinhead|Zippy]] Stories'' (1986). {{ISBN|0-86719-325-5}} * Fitzgerald, F. Stop and Marian Kester. ''[[Dead Kennedys]]: The Unauthorized Version'' (1983) {{ISBN|0-86719-312-3}} * [[JT LeRoy|LeRoy, J. T.]] with illustrations by Cherry Hood. ''[[Todd Schorr#American Surreal|American Surreal]]'' (2008) ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area|Companies|Comics}} *[[List of book distributors]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.lastgasp.com}} * {{gcdb publisher|id=351|title=Last Gasp}} *{{Comicbookdb|type=publisher|id=1380|title=Last Gasp}} * [http://laughingsquid.com/last-gasp-holiday-party-photos/ Photos from the 2005 charity fundraising party held at Last Gasp offices] * [http://laughingsquid.com/burritos-beer-cheer-2007-the-annual-last-gasp-holiday-party/ Photos from the 2007 charity fundraising party held at Last Gasp offices] * [http://laughingsquid.com/last-gasp-holiday-party-2008-burritos-beer-cheer/ Photos from the 2008 charity fundraising party held at Last Gasp offices] {{Underground comix publishers}} {{Comic book publishers in North America navbox}} [[Category:Comic book publishing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Underground comix]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1970]] [[Category:Publishers of adult comics]] [[Category:1970 establishments in California]] [[Category:Last Gasp]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=April 2018}} {{essay|date=April 2018}} {{Orphan|date=May 2018}} }}
'''Left-right asymmetry''' (LR asymmetry) refers to differences in structure ([[Symmetry in biology|symmetry]] breaking) across the mediolateral (left and right) plane in animals. This plane is defined with respect to the [[Anatomical terms of location|anteroposterior]] and [[Anatomical terms of location|dorsoventral]] axes and is perpendicular to both. Because the left-right plane is not strictly an axis (as it is not established through a [[morphogen]] gradient), to create asymmetry, the left and right sides need to be patterned separately.<ref>Palmer, A. R. (2004). Symmetry breaking and the evolution of development. ''Science'', ''306''(5697), 828-833</ref>
LR asymmetry is pervasive throughout [[Animal|metazoans]] and present throughout every major lineage. Notable examples include the large and small claws of the [[fiddler crab]], the left offset of the vertebrate heart, asymmetrical gut coiling in ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]],'' and dextral (clockwise) and sinistral (counterclockwise) coiling of [[Gastropoda|gastropods]]. This asymmetry can be restricted to a specific organ or feature, as in the crab claws, or be expressed throughout the entire body as in snails.
== Developmental basis == Components of the [[Nodal signaling pathway]] have been implicated in left-right determination in a diverse set of taxa.<ref name=":0">Levin et al. (1995). A molecular pathway determining left-right asymmetry in chick embryogenesis. ''Cell'' 82, 803-814.</ref><ref name=":1">Coutelis, J. B., González‐Morales, N., Géminard, C., & Noselli, S. (2014). Diversity and convergence in the mechanisms establishing L/R asymmetry in metazoa. ''EMBO Reports'', e201438972.</ref> While the mechanisms to set up the left-right sides appear to differ markedly among groups of organisms, ''[[NODAL|Nodal]]'' is consistently deployed in most of the lineages that have been examined (except for [[ecdysozoa]]ns).<ref name=":1" /> In established model organisms such as mouse, chick, ''D. melanogaster,'' and ''[[African clawed frog|Xenopus]],'' ongoing research has begun to focus on cellular level symmetry-breaking mechanisms (e.g. cytoskeletal chirality, ciliary flow) that may lead to differential expression of molecules such as Nodal.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tee|first=Yee Han|last2=Shemesh|first2=Tom|last3=Thiagarajan|first3=Visalatchi|last4=Hariadi|first4=Rizal Fajar|last5=Anderson|first5=Karen L.|last6=Page|first6=Christopher|last7=Volkmann|first7=Niels|last8=Hanein|first8=Dorit|last9=Sivaramakrishnan|first9=Sivaraj|title=Cellular chirality arising from the self-organization of the actin cytoskeleton|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ncb3137|journal=Nature Cell Biology|volume=17|issue=4|pages=445–457|doi=10.1038/ncb3137}}</ref>
=== Vertebrates === ''Nodal'' was first described in the chick embryo, where genes ''activin receptor IIa, [[Sonic hedgehog]] (Shh),'' and ''chick nodal-related 1 (cNR-1)'' were found to be asymmetrically expressed across [[Primitive knot|Hensen’s node]] with ''cnR-1'' expressed on the left side.<ref name=":0" /> Misexpressing ''Shh'' or ''activin receptor IIa'' on the right side randomized heart asymmetry in the chick. This asymmetrical gene expression appears to be triggered by cell movements in the node.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gros|first=Jerome|last2=Feistel|first2=Kerstin|last3=Viebahn|first3=Christoph|last4=Blum|first4=Martin|last5=Tabin|first5=Clifford J.|date=2009-05-15|title=Cell Movements at Hensen’s Node Establish Left/Right Asymmetric Gene Expression in the Chick|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/324/5929/941|journal=Science|volume=324|issue=5929|pages=941–944|doi=10.1126/science.1172478|issn=0036-8075|pmc=2993078|pmid=19359542}}</ref>
In mouse, the left side is distinguished from the right through Nodal flow.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nonaka|first=Shigenori|last2=Tanaka|first2=Yosuke|last3=Okada|first3=Yasushi|last4=Takeda|first4=Sen|last5=Harada|first5=Akihiro|last6=Kanai|first6=Yoshimitsu|last7=Kido|first7=Mizuho|last8=Hirokawa|first8=Nobutaka|title=Randomization of Left–Right Asymmetry due to Loss of Nodal Cilia Generating Leftward Flow of Extraembryonic Fluid in Mice Lacking KIF3B Motor Protein|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0092-8674(00)81705-5|journal=Cell|volume=95|issue=6|pages=829–837|doi=10.1016/s0092-8674(00)81705-5}}</ref> Originally described from ''inversus viscerum (iv)'' and ''inversion of embryonic turning (inv)'' mouse mutants, which are characterized by a randomization of left-right phenotypes, Nodal flow refers to the movement of nodal cilia to create a leftward flow of extraembryonic fluid.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Okada|first=Yasushi|last2=Nonaka|first2=Shigenori|last3=Tanaka|first3=Yosuke|last4=Saijoh|first4=Yukio|last5=Hamada|first5=Hiroshi|last6=Hirokawa|first6=Nobutaka|date=1999-10-01|title=Abnormal Nodal Flow Precedes Situs Inversus in iv and inv mice|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1097276500801975|journal=Molecular Cell|volume=4|issue=4|pages=459–468|doi=10.1016/S1097-2765(00)80197-5}}</ref> Carried in this leftward movement is Nodal, a signaling peptide from the [[Transforming growth factor beta|TGF-β]] family necessary to pattern left-right determination.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brennan|first=Jane|last2=Norris|first2=Dominic P.|last3=Robertson|first3=Elizabeth J.|date=2002-09-15|title=Nodal activity in the node governs left-right asymmetry|url=http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/16/18/2339|journal=Genes & Development|volume=16|issue=18|pages=2339–2344|doi=10.1101/gad.1016202|issn=0890-9369|pmc=187443|pmid=12231623}}</ref> In the lateral plate mesoderm, Nodal then activates a positive feedback loop promoting its expression and its downstream effector ''[[PITX2|Pitx2]].'' To prevent expansion to the rightward portion of the embryo, Nodal activates ''Lefty1'' and ''Lefty2,'' which repress the Nodal signaling pathway by competing with Nodal binding sites.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meno|first=Chikara|last2=Shimono|first2=Akihiko|last3=Saijoh|first3=Yukio|last4=Yashiro|first4=Kenta|last5=Mochida|first5=Kyoko|last6=Ohishi|first6=Sachiko|last7=Noji|first7=Sumihare|last8=Kondoh|first8=Hisato|last9=Hamada|first9=Hiroshi|date=1998-08-07|title=lefty-1 Is Required for Left-Right Determination as a Regulator of lefty-2 and nodal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867400814725|journal=Cell|volume=94|issue=3|pages=287–297|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(00)81472-5}}</ref>
Because Nodal flow through ciliary movement is not present in all vertebrates (e.g. the chick), asymmetric gene expression must be established in another way. One such idea posits that [[ion channel]]s and pumps (H+/K+ ATPase) generate differences in voltage and pH across the mediolateral plane, thus providing gradients to orient signaling molecules.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levin|first=Michael|last2=Thorlin|first2=Thorleif|last3=Robinson|first3=Kenneth R.|last4=Nogi|first4=Taisaku|last5=Mercola|first5=Mark|date=2002-10-04|title=Asymmetries in H+/K+-ATPase and Cell Membrane Potentials Comprise a Very Early Step in Left-Right Patterning|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S009286740200939X|journal=Cell|volume=111|issue=1|pages=77–89|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(02)00939-X}}</ref>
=== Non-vertebrate deuterostomes === Recently, work has shown that the Nodal-Pitx2 pathway is present and functional in the non-vertebrate [[deuterostome]]s (tunicates, sea urchins).<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Shimeld|first=Sebastian M.|last2=Levin|first2=Michael|date=2006-06-01|title=Evidence for the regulation of left-right asymmetry in Ciona intestinalis by ion flux|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/dvdy.20792/abstract|journal=Developmental Dynamics|volume=235|issue=6|pages=1543–1553|doi=10.1002/dvdy.20792|issn=1097-0177}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Molina|first=M Dolores|last2=de Crozé|first2=Noémie|last3=Haillot|first3=Emmanuel|last4=Lepage|first4=Thierry|date=2013-08-01|title=Nodal: master and commander of the dorsal–ventral and left–right axes in the sea urchin embryo|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959437X13000646|journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development|series=Developmental mechanisms, patterning and evolution|volume=23|issue=4|pages=445–453|doi=10.1016/j.gde.2013.04.010}}</ref> In tunicate ([[Ascidiacea|ascidian]]) ''[[Ciona intestinalis]]'' and ''[[Sea pineapple|Halocynthia roretzi]]'', ''Nodal'' is expressed on the left side of the developing embryo and leads to downstream expression of ''Pitx2.'' At earlier stages, similar H+/K+ ATPase ion channels are reported to be necessary for correct left-right patterning.<ref name=":2" /> While the role of cilia here is still unclear, one study observes that large-scale embryonic movements are required for left-right determination in ''H. roretzi,'' and that this movement is possibly achieved through ciliary movements.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nishide|first=Kazuhiko|last2=Mugitani|first2=Michio|last3=Kumano|first3=Gaku|last4=Nishida|first4=Hiroki|date=2012-04-15|title=Neurula rotation determines left-right asymmetry in ascidian tadpole larvae|url=http://dev.biologists.org/content/139/8/1467|journal=Development|volume=139|issue=8|pages=1467–1475|doi=10.1242/dev.076083|issn=0950-1991|pmid=22399684}}</ref>
In the sea urchin, ''Nodal'' is expressed on the right side of the embryo, in contrast to the tunicate and vertebrate condition on the left side.<ref name=":3" /> Because [[protostome]]s appear to also express ''Nodal'' on their right side instead of the left (discussed below), some have suggested that this lends further evidence for the dorsoventral [[Inversion (evolutionary biology)|inversion]] hypothesis.<ref name=":1" />
=== Protostomes ===
==== Ecdysozoa ==== While ''D. melanogaster'' and nematode ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' do show left-right asymmetry, the Nodal signaling pathway itself is absent in Ecdysozoa.<ref name=":1" /> Instead, cytoskeletal regulators such as Myo31DF, a type ID unconventional myosin, have been found to control left-right asymmetry in organ systems such as genitalia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spéder|first=Pauline|last2=Ádám|first2=Géza|last3=Noselli|first3=Stéphane|date=2006-04-06|title=Type ID unconventional myosin controls left–right asymmetry in Drosophila|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v440/n7085/full/nature04623.html|journal=Nature|volume=440|issue=7085|pages=803–807|doi=10.1038/nature04623|issn=0028-0836}}</ref>
==== Lophotrochozoa ==== Unlike in Ecdysozoa, the Nodal-Pitx2 pathways have been identified in many lineages within the [[Lophotrochozoa]]ns.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Martín-Durán|first=José M.|last2=Vellutini|first2=Bruno C.|last3=Hejnol|first3=Andreas|date=2016-12-19|title=Embryonic chirality and the evolution of spiralian left–right asymmetries|url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/371/1710/20150411|journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B|volume=371|issue=1710|pages=20150411|doi=10.1098/rstb.2015.0411|issn=0962-8436|pmid=27821523|pmc=5104510}}</ref> When found in [[brachiopod]]s and molluscs, these genes are asymmetrically expressed on the right.<ref name=":4" /> Platyhelminthes, annelids, and nermeteans lack a Nodal orthologue and instead only express Pitx2, which was expressed in association to the nervous system.<ref name=":4" />
== Whole body left-right asymmetry in gastropods == Whole body inversion is observed as chiral (dextral, sinistral) coiling in gastropods. While dextral coiling is the most common as it appears in 90-99% of living species, sinistral species still have arisen many times.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Asami|first=Takahiro|last2=Cowie|first2=Robert H.|last3=Ohbayashi|first3=Kako|date=1998-01-01|title=Evolution of Mirror Images by Sexually Asymmetric Mating Behavior in Hermaphroditic Snails|jstor=10.1086/286163|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=152|issue=2|pages=225–236|doi=10.1086/286163}}</ref>
=== Developmental basis of shell coiling === Gastropods undergo [[Cleavage (embryo)|spiral cleavage]], a feature commonly seen in lophotrochozoans. As the embryo divides, quartets of cells are oriented at angles to each other. In the snail ''Lymnaea stagnalis'', the direction of rotation during the first cell division signals whether the adult will show dextral or sinistral coiling,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Meshcheryakov|first=V. N.|last2=Beloussov|first2=L. V.|title=Asymmetrical rotations of blastomeres in early cleavage of gastropoda|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00848080|journal=Wilhelm Roux's archives of developmental biology|volume=177|issue=3|pages=193–203|doi=10.1007/BF00848080|issn=0340-0794}}</ref> At the third cleavage (8-cell stage), spindles in dextral snails are inclined clockwise whereas they are counterclockwise in sinistral snails.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Shibazaki|first=Yuichiro|last2=Shimizu|first2=Miho|last3=Kuroda|first3=Reiko|date=2004-08-24|title=Body Handedness Is Directed by Genetically Determined Cytoskeletal Dynamics in the Early Embryo|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982204005640|journal=Current Biology|volume=14|issue=16|pages=1462–1467|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2004.08.018}}</ref> Furthermore, injecting ''L. peregra'' sinistral eggs with the cytoplasm of dextral eggs before the second polar body formation will reverse the polarity of the sinistral embryos.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Freeman|first=Gary|last2=Lundelius|first2=Judith W.|title=The developmental genetics of dextrality and sinistrality in the gastropodLymnaea peregra|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00848443|journal=Wilhelm Roux's archives of developmental biology|volume=191|issue=2|pages=69–83|doi=10.1007/BF00848443|issn=0340-0794}}</ref> These data show that chirality is heritable and maternally deposited in ''Lymnaea''.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />
Several studies have begun to investigate the molecular basis of this inheritance. ''Nodal'' and ''Pitx2'' are expressed on different sides of the ''L. stagnalis'' embryo depending on its chirality – right for dextral, left for sinistral.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grande|first=Cristina|last2=Patel|first2=Nipam H.|date=2009-02-19|title=Nodal signalling is involved in left–right asymmetry in snails|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v457/n7232/full/nature07603.html|journal=Nature|volume=457|issue=7232|pages=1007–1011|doi=10.1038/nature07603|issn=0028-0836|pmc=2661027|pmid=19098895}}</ref> Downstream of ''Nodal, decapentaplegic (dpp),'' shows the same expression pattern.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Shimizu|first=Keisuke|last2=Iijima|first2=Minoru|last3=Setiamarga|first3=Davin HE|last4=Sarashina|first4=Isao|last5=Kudoh|first5=Tetsuhiro|last6=Asami|first6=Takahiro|last7=Gittenberger|first7=Edi|last8=Endo|first8=Kazuyoshi|date=2013-01-01|title=Left-right asymmetric expression of dpp in the mantle of gastropods correlates with asymmetric shell coiling|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/2041-9139-4-15|journal=EvoDevo|volume=4|pages=15|doi=10.1186/2041-9139-4-15|issn=2041-9139|pmc=3680195|pmid=23711320}}</ref> In limpets (gastropods without coiled shells) ''dpp'' is expressed symmetrically in ''Patella vulgata'' and ''Nipponacmea fuscoviridis''.<ref name=":8" /> Additionally, in ''N. fuscoviridis'', ''dpp'' has been shown to drive cell proliferation<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kurita|first=Yoshihisa|last2=Wada|first2=Hiroshi|date=2011-04-27|title=Evidence that gastropod torsion is driven by asymmetric cell proliferation activated by TGF-β signalling|url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2011/04/16/rsbl.2011.0263|journal=Biology Letters|pages=rsbl20110263|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2011.0263|issn=1744-9561|pmc=3169068|pmid=21525052}}</ref>
Upstream of Nodal, ''Lsdia1/2'' have been implicated in controlling ''L. stagnalis'' chirality.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Davison|first=Angus|last2=McDowell|first2=Gary S.|last3=Holden|first3=Jennifer M.|last4=Johnson|first4=Harriet F.|last5=Koutsovoulos|first5=Georgios D.|last6=Liu|first6=M. Maureen|last7=Hulpiau|first7=Paco|last8=Roy|first8=Frans Van|last9=Wade|first9=Christopher M.|title=Formin Is Associated with Left-Right Asymmetry in the Pond Snail and the Frog|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2015.12.071|journal=Current Biology|volume=26|issue=5|pages=654–660|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2015.12.071|pmc=4791482|pmid=26923788}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Kuroda|first=Reiko|last2=Fujikura|first2=Kohei|last3=Abe|first3=Masanori|last4=Hosoiri|first4=Yuji|last5=Asakawa|first5=Shuichi|last6=Shimizu|first6=Miho|last7=Umeda|first7=Shin|last8=Ichikawa|first8=Futaba|last9=Takahashi|first9=Hiromi|date=2016-10-06|title=Diaphanous gene mutation affects spiral cleavage and chirality in snails|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=6|doi=10.1038/srep34809|issn=2045-2322|pmc=5052593|pmid=27708420}}</ref> Davison et al. (2016) mapped the “chirality locus” to a 0.4 Mb region and determined that ''Lsdia2'' is the likely candidate for determining dextral or sinistral coiling.<ref name=":9" /> This is a diaphanous-related formin gene involved in cytoskeleton formation.<ref name=":9" /> Dextral embryos treated with drugs that inhibited formin activity phenocopied the sinistral condition. Concurrent work from Kuroda et al. (2016) identified the same ''Lsdia2'' gene (called ''Lsdia1'' in their study) but failed to reproduce the formin inhibition results in the Davison et al. study.<ref name=":10" /> Additionally, Kuroda et al. (2016) did not find asymmetrically expressed ''Lsdia2'' as was seen in the Davison et al. (2016) study.
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Symmetry]] [[Category:Animal anatomy]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=November 2018}} {{refimprove|date=November 2018}} }} {{short description|Bangladeshi artist and poet (b. 1966)}} {{Infobox artist | name = Maksudul Ahsan | image = Maksudul Ahsan.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Maksudul Ahsan | birth_date = {{birth date|1966|02|03|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chandpur Sadar Upazila|Chandpur]], [[Bangladesh]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Bangladeshi | field = | training = Institute of Fine Arts of [[Dhaka University]] (1987) | movement = | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Maksudul Ahsan''' (born February 3, 1966) is a [[Bangladesh]]i artist and poet.
== Early life == Ahsan was born in [[Chandpur Sadar Upazila|Chandpur]]. In 1987, he graduated from the Institute of Fine Arts of [[Dhaka University]]. In 1989 he obtained a master's degree there. In 1992, he received a diploma from the Academy of Planning and Development.
== Career == In 1989 he became a teacher of the College of Art in [[Khulna]]. In 1991 he became artistic editor of the weekly ''Shamoy Songglap'' in Dhaka. From 1994-2002, he lived and worked in [[Delhi]] (India). In 2008-2009, he was the editor of the weekly ''Shubarno Shodesh''. In 2011 he became the Chief Executive Director of the Gallery of Modern Art "Basilo" (Dhaka).
== Creativity == He works with watercolor and oil. He is an adherent of traditions in art and an impulsive improviser. His pictures are characterized by a powerful pastosic{{what?|date=October 2018}} painting technique smearing bright contrasting colors, with converging and diverging lines. He produces moderately realistic as well as abstract images.<ref>"Maksudul's fantasy in painting" // «The Asian Age», February 13, 2017</ref> He illustrates books.<ref>Aminur Rahman. The Sculpture (English and Spanish Edition). London: Aark Arts, 2002</ref> He published two collections of poems, ''Bashwashi Korotol'' and ''Shoundarjyer Staba'', in 1989.
== Exhibitions == The first solo exhibition of the artist took place in the gallery "La Gallery" in Dhaka in 1994. Since then he has held 12 solo exhibitions in Bangladesh, India and Canada, and participated in more than 40 collective exhibitions in his homeland and abroad (India, Canada, Malaysia).<ref>RS Yadav. «Making the Best of Opportunity» // Maksudul Ahsan. Selective Works of 25 Years. Dhaka: BANDHAN art and culture society, 2016</ref> In 2016, the National Gallery of Bangladesh held a retrospective, dedicated to the 25th anniversary of his creative activity.<ref>"Painter Maksudul's retro underway" // «The New Age», Oct 31,2016</ref> He organized eight art workshops in Dhaka, Delhi and Calcutta with the participation of artists from the countries of the [[South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation]] (SAARC).
==Collections== The artist's paintings are kept in the [[National Museum of Bangladesh]], in the National Picture Gallery of Bangladesh, in the Shilpakala Academy (Dhaka), in the Sheraton and Pan Pacific Sonargaon hotels, the Ravi Jain Memorial Foundation in Delhi, the Dhohomi Mal and "Kunika" galleries (Delhi), as well as in private collections in Australia, England, Bangladesh, Germany, India, Canada, China, the Netherlands, Pakistan, Switzerland and the US.
== Social activities == He is one of the founders of the society "Jania Abritti Charcha Kendra" (1987), Executive Director of the South Asian Society of Art and Culture (since 2003), Secretary General of the Arts and Cultural Society "Bandhan" (since 2004).
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ahsan, Maksudul}} [[Category:Bengali male artists]] [[Category:Bangladeshi artists]] [[Category:Muslim artists]] [[Category:Bangladeshi painters]] [[Category:Modern artists]] [[Category:Modern painters]] [[Category:Artists from Dhaka]] [[Category:20th-century Bangladeshi artists]] [[Category:20th-century Bangladeshi painters]] [[Category:Bangladeshi art]] [[Category:Bangladeshi culture]] [[Category:Bengali Muslims]] [[Category:Bangladeshi Muslims]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Dhaka alumni]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[File:Frits Van den Berghe - Malpertuus.JPG|thumb|''Malpertuus'' by [[Frits Van den Berghe]] ([[Museum of Fine Arts, Ghent]])]]
'''Maleperduis''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|m|æ|l|ᵻ|ˈ|p|ɜːr|dj|u|ᵻ|s}}; {{Lang-fr|Maupertuis}}; {{Lang-de|Malepartus}}; {{Lang-nl|Maupertuus}}; {{Lang-enm|Maleperduys}}), also spelled '''Malperdy''', is [[Reynard the Fox|Reynard the Fox's]] principal hideaway in the [[medieval literature|medieval tales]] of this figure of legend. The name of the castle is most likely an old misspelling of the French word "Millepertuis", meaning "[[St. John's Wort]]", which was considered a sacred plant during the days the Reynard cycle was first written.
[[Labyrinth]]ine Maleperduys is full of holes, crooked and long, with multiple exits, which Reynard can open and shut to elude his enemies. Full of secret chambers and passageways, in [[William Caxton|William Caxton's]] ''The Historie of Reynart the Foxe'' (1485) the [[castle]] of Maleperduys is described as the "best and the fastest burgh that [Reynard] had. There lay he in when he had need, and was in any dread or fear." (Chapter VII, ''How Bruin the Bear was sped of Reynard the Fox''). Over time, the word came to mean a place of refuge.
It is also the title of a horror novel, written in 1943 by the Belgian author, [[Jean Ray (author)|Jean Ray]]. In 1972, it was made into a film, ''[[Malpertuis (film)|Malpertuis]]'', directed by [[Harry Kümel]] and starring [[Orson Welles]].
{{Reynard}}
[[Category:Medieval legends]] [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Fictional castles and fortresses]] [[Category:Reynard cycle]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #0080FF | name = Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1954}} | nationality = [[Haida people|Haida]] | field = [[Painting]], [[sculpture]], [[Totem pole|carving]] | movement = [[Visual arts by indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous art]], [[Haida manga]] | works = ''Hachidori''
''Coppers from the Hood''
''Pedal to the Meddle'' | website = http://mny.ca }} '''Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas''' is an award-winning visual contemporary artist, author and speaker. His work has been seen in public spaces, museums, galleries and private collections across globe. Institutional collections include the British Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Seattle Art Museum and Vancouver Art Gallery. A lot of Michael's art is inspired by the work he does with The Christensen Fund. The Christensen Fund is a private foundation that buttresses the efforts of people and institutions inspired by a bio and culturally diverse world infused with artistic expression and lives and environments that are beautiful, bountiful and resilient. ==Early life== Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas was born in 1954 in Masset, Haida Gwaii. He is a descendant of the influential artists, [[Isabella Edenshaw]], [[Charles Edenshaw]]. Yahgulanaas was a prolific young artist who soon covered the walls and ceilings of his bedroom with drawings. When those spaces were filled he found the fingernails of schoolmates to be an interesting platte for intricate multicoloured paintings. His artistic passion was curtailed somewhat in the decades that he in elected and volunteer public work including the creation of an multicultural community endowment, the [http://www.gwaiitrust.com/aboutus/ourhistory.html Gwaii Trust]. ==Art career== Yahgulanaas's work has been seen in public spaces, museums, galleries, and private collections across North America, Europe, Asia, Australia, and the Middle East. His visual practice encompasses a variety of different art forms including: large-scale public art projects, mixed media sculptures and canvases, re-purposed automobile parts, acrylics, watercolours, ink drawings, and illustrated publications. Exploring themes of identity, environmentalism, and the human condition he uses art to communicate a world view that while particular to Haida Gwaii, his ancestral North Pacific archipelago, is also relevant to a contemporary and internationally engaged audience. The original five–meter long mural that was published in 2009 as ''RED: A Haida manga'' is on a multi-year exhibit tour. Another book, ''Hachidori'' has sold over 100,000 copies in Japan with a single-day record sale of 20,000 copies. ''Flight of the Hummingbird'', first published in North America and now available in five languages, is also a bestseller and includes essays contributed by the [[Dalai Lama]] and [[Nobel Peace prize]] winner [[Wangari Maathai]]. ''Declaration of Interdependence'' by Dr [[David Suzuki]] was illustrated by Yahgulanaas.[http://www.davidsuzuki.org/about/declaration/ The Declaration of Interdependence's web site], retrieved 2013-01-11[http://www.dmpibooks.com/author/michael-nicoll-yahgulanaas Author bio at his publisher's web site], {{ISBN|1553653726}}, retrieved 2013-01-11. Yahgulanaas's works in metal include commissions from the [[British Museum]] (2010), The City of [[Vancouver]] (2011) and the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] organizing committee. In 2015, his sculpture of a [[sei whale]] was unveiled at the [[Vancouver International Airport]].{{cite news|title=Michael Yahgulanaas's new art piece SEI unveiled at Vancouver airport|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/michael-yahgulanaas-s-new-art-piece-sei-unveiled-at-vancouver-airport-1.3145562|accessdate=10 July 2015|agency=[[CBC News]]|date=2015-07-09}} In January 2016, his sculpture Yelthadaas from the Coppers From the Hood series joined the permanent collection at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in [[New York City]].{{cite news|title=Yelthadaas|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/682959|accessdate=3 Jan 2016|agency=[[The Metropolitan Museum of Art]]}}. This work was put up on display in 2017. The piece hangs in Gallery 399, between the Modern and Contemporary Art wing and the Rockefeller Wing, where contemporary art borders Indigenous art. Since 2009, Yahgulanaas has been a member of the board of the [[Museum of Anthropology at UBC]]. ===Haida manga=== Although Yahgulanaas trained under master carvers, his brief exposure to Chinese brush techniques with Cai Ben Kwan encouraged a departure from the typical expressions of the Haida art form and the development of a new genre of narrative art called "Haida manga."[http://www.coastalartbeat.ca/2011/?p=957 "Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas Graphic Art Production", about Yahgulanaas's "Old Growth" gallery showing, at Grunt Gallery]. retrieved 2013-01-11. Haida Manga blends North Pacific Indigenous iconographies and framelines with the graphic dynamism of Asian manga. Haida Manga is committed to hybridity as a positive force that opens a third space for critical engagement. It offers an empowering and playful way of viewing and engaging with social issues as it seeks participation, dialogue, reflection, and action. ==Published works== [http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/sgc-cms/expositions-exhibitions/bill_reid/english/background/michaelnicoll.html "Michael Nicoll: Artist Profile."] ''Virtual Museum Canada.'' Retrieved 1 April 2013. *''War of the Blink'' (2017) *''The Seriousness of Play'', Nicola Levell (2016) * ''Old Growth: Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas'', Liz Park, ed. {{ISBN|978-1897476963}} (2012) *''The Canoe He Called Loo Taas''— illustrations (2010) *''The Little Hummingbird'' (2010) *''The Declaration of Interdependence''— illustrations (2010) *''The Canoe He Called Loo Taas'', {{ISBN|9780978255367}}, (2010) *''Red: A Haida Manga'', {{ISBN|978-1-55365-353-0}}, (2009) *''RED, A Haida Manga'' (2009) *''Flight of the Hummingbird'' (2008) *''Hachidori'' (2005) *''A Lousy Tale'' (2004) *''The Last Voyage of the Black Ship'' (2001) *''A Tale of Two Shamans'' (2001) ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://mny.ca/en/ Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas], official website * [http://www.haidamanga.com Haida manga] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yahgulanaas, Michael Nicoll}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian comics artists]] [[Category:Haida artists]] [[Category:First Nations painters]] [[Category:First Nations sculptors]]

{{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox building | name = Odeon Theatre | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = {{Plainlist| * Tuam Street Hall * Tuam Street Theatre * Opera House }} | alternate_names = | image = Odeon Theatre in Tuam Street, Christchurch.jpg | caption = The Odeon Theatre in Tuam Street, Christchurch (October 2010) | image_size = 320px | altitude = | building_type = Former theatre | architectural_style = [[Italianate architecture]] with [[Venetian Gothic architecture|Venetian Gothic]] elements | structural_system = Unreinforced masonry | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = [[Christchurch Central City]] | address = 214 Tuam Street | location_town = [[Christchurch]] | location_country = [[New Zealand]] | map_type = New Zealand Christchurch street | map_alt = Map of Christchurch Central City | map_caption = Location within the [[Christchurch Central City]] | map_size = 300 | coordinates = {{coord|43|32|8|S|172|38|21|E|region:NZ_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | start_date = | completion_date = 1883 | inauguration_date = {{Start date|1883|07|20|df=y}} | renovation_date = 1927 | demolition_date = September 2012 | destruction_date = 22 February 2011 | height = <!-- {{convert|39.65|m|ft|abbr=on}} --> | diameter = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = two | floor_area = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | main_contractor = | architect = Thomas Stoddart Lambert | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | ren_architect = [[Sidney Luttrell]] | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | embedded = {{designation list|embed=yes|designation1=NZ Category I|designation1_number=3140|designation1_date=26 November 1981}} | url = | references = {{NZHPT|3140|Odeon Theatre|18 September 2012}} }} The '''Odeon Theatre''' in [[Christchurch]] was the oldest masonry theatre in New Zealand, and one of only three remaining purpose-built 19th-century theatres in the country. The building has had different names over the years, and was put to many different uses. It was damaged beyond repair in the 22 February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]] and partially demolished in September 2012. The theatre was recognised as a Category I heritage building by the [[New Zealand Historic Places Trust]], with registration number 3140. One of its most notable aspects was its use as a public meeting venue of [[Kate Sheppard]] during her [[Women's suffrage in New Zealand|women's suffrage]] campaign.
==History== [[File:Public hall (later St James Theatre).jpg|thumb|left|The original facade of the Tuam Street Hall including a significant parapet (removed in 1960)]] A syndicate of citizens formed the Public Hall Company Ltd and through this commissioned the building.<ref name="register Odeon">{{NZHPT|3140|Odeon Theatre|18 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Library entry">{{cite web|title=Public hall (later St James Theatre), Tuam Street, Christchurch |url= http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/Photos/Disc12/IMG0072.asp |publisher=Christchurch City Libraries|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> The theatre, located in 214 Tuam Street, was built in 1883 to a design by Thomas Stoddart Lambert (1840–1915).<ref name="register Odeon" /> It had a capacity of 2,200 people, 600 of whom fitted into the gallery. The stage was initially {{convert|60|ft}} wide and {{convert|40|ft}} deep. The building was opened on 20 July 1883, with the [[Mayor of Christchurch]], [[George Ruddenklau]], presiding.<ref>{{cite news|title=Young Men's Christian Association|url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=TS18830721.2.22 |accessdate=18 September 2012 |newspaper=The Star|date=21 July 1883|issue=4750|page=4}}</ref>
[[File:Final curtain for the Odeon Theatre, Christchurch 12.JPG|thumb|left|The final curtain for the Odeon Theatre]] The building's original name was '''Tuam Street Hall''' or '''Tuam Street Theatre'''. The building had a variety of rather diverse uses: public meeting place, entertainment, exhibitions, roller skate rink, and other activities. In 1893, it was used by [[Kate Sheppard]] for [[Women's suffrage in New Zealand|women's suffrage]].<ref name="register Odeon" /> After the 1893 Electoral Act was passed on 19 September 1893, which meant that New Zealand women were the first in the world to be granted the right to vote,<ref>{{cite web|title= Votes for Women|url= http://www.elections.org.nz/study/education-centre/history/votes-for-women.html|publisher= Elections New Zealand|accessdate= 18 September 2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120819080640/http://www.elections.org.nz/study/education-centre/history/votes-for-women.html|archivedate= 19 August 2012|df= dmy-all}}</ref> an enrolment meeting was held by Sheppard at Tuam Street Hall on 26 September in preparation for the [[New Zealand general election, 1893|1893 election]] in late November.<ref>{{cite news|title=Women's Franchise |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=CHP18930926.2.20 |accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=[[The Press]] |volume=L |issue=8597 |date=26 September 1893|page=3}}</ref> Despite rather unfavourable weather, 600 women were enrolled that day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Enrolment Meeting|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TS18930926.2.37 |accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=The Star|date=26 September 1893|issue=4758|page=3}}</ref>
In 1894, the name changed to '''Opera House'''. [[Vaudeville]] was the main form of entertainment around the turn of the century, and [[John Fuller (theatre manager)|John Fuller]]'s son Benjamin started their theatre company's involvement with the building in 1903.<ref name="Library entry" /><ref name="DNZB Fuller">{{DNZB|Downes|Peter |2f29|Fuller, John - Biography|18 September 2012}}</ref>
[[Sidney and Alfred Luttrell|Sidney Luttrell]] was commissioned to remodel the building's interior, and the modified space opened on 26 December 1927, providing seating for 1,300 people. The dimensions of the stage were changed to {{convert|60|ft}} wide, {{convert|60|ft}} deep, and {{convert|40|ft}} high, and there were then 19 dressing rooms.<ref name="Library entry" /> With the introduction of film in 1930, the name was once again changed, this time to '''St James'''. The stage remained, though, and the building was sometimes used for other purposes, for example live entertainment.<ref name="Library entry" /> St James closed for a period during the [[Great Depression]].<ref name="register Odeon" /> Notable performers during the 1940s include the [[Trapp Family Singers]], [[Stanley Holloway]], [[Johnny Devlin]], [[Laurence Olivier]], and Olivier's second wife [[Vivien Leigh]].<ref name="register Odeon" />
[[File:Kate Sheppard.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Kate Sheppard]] made extensive use of the Tuam Street Hall during her women's suffrage campaign]] Ownership changed in 1960 to Kerridge-Odeon Ltd, and the building was renamed '''Odeon''' and reopened on 27 September 1960. Extensive changes were undertaken, including the removal of the parapet, reduction of seating down to 720, updating of the cinema equipment, and introduction of a coffee lounge.<ref name="register Odeon" /><ref name="Library entry" /> Through competition with television, patronage declined and the theatre eventually closed. The building was purchased in 1983 by the [[Sydenham, New Zealand|Sydenham]] Assembly of God, who used it for religious gatherings from 1985.<ref name="register Odeon" />
The building was bought in 2003 by a group of businessmen, who in May 2004 applied for demolition consent. In response, the Odeon Theatre Trust was formed by residents concerned for the preservation of the building.<ref name="register Odeon" /> Ownership changed again in December 2006, when Property Ventures Ltd, the development company of [[David Henderson (Christchurch, New Zealand)|David Henderson]], purchased it.<ref>{{cite news|last=Solotti|first=Rachel|title=Theatre set to star once again |url= http://www.starcanterbury.co.nz/news/theatre-set-to-star-once-again/971397/ |accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=The Star|date=15 December 2006}}</ref> Property Ventures had its office in a building diagonally opposite the Odeon Theatre at 179 Tuam Street.<ref>{{cite web|title=Property Ventures|url= http://www.zenbu.co.nz/entry/1112002-property-ventures |publisher=zenbu |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> When Henderson's companies got into financial difficulties, [[Christchurch City Council]] controversially bought five of his inner city land holdings in August 2008, but not the Odeon Theatre.<ref>{{cite news|title=Business lobby questions Henderson deals |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/575573 |accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=[[The Press]]|date=11 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Odeon Theatre repaired |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/our-communities/659771/Odeon-Theatre-repaired |accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=[[The Press]]|date=5 October 2008}}</ref> Henderson was placed in bankruptcy in November 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=van Beynen|first=Martin |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/money/4403232/Property-developer-David-Henderson-placed-in-bankruptcy |title=Property developer David Henderson placed in bankruptcy |authorlink=Martin van Beynen |date=29 November 2010 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
[[File:SOL Square - Yellow Cross.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The Yellow Cross bar in SOL Square, utilising the cross from the Odeon Theatre fitted by the Sydenham Assembly of God]] During the years of the Sydenham Assembly of God ownership, a large yellow illuminated cross was displayed on the theatre's frontage (the bracket still visible in photos post-2008). Henderson used the cross in the SOL Square development (located on the north side of the Property Ventures head office) and styled one of the bars as the Yellow Cross, prominently displaying the cross on the roof apex.<ref>{{cite web |title=SOL Square |url= https://www.flickr.com/photos/12265809@N07/3034015490/ |publisher=flickr|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref>
In 2009, Christchurch actor and director [[Mark Hadlow]] campaigned for the Odeon Theatre to be turned into an arts complex for an estimated NZ$60m.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gates |first=Charlie |title=Hadlow wants to turn Odeon into NoeDo |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/our-communities/3184268/Hadlow-wants-to-turn-Odeon-into-NoeDo |accessdate=7 February 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=22 December 2012}}</ref>
==Heritage listing== On 26 November 1981, the building was registered by the New Zealand Historic Places Trust as a Category I historic place, with the registration number 3140. The building is recognised as the once largest public meeting venue in Christchurch, the oldest remaining theatre in Christchurch, and the then country's oldest masonry theatre. Of significance is the use of the building by Kate Sheppard. Another aspect is the building's association with two important Christchurch designers, Lambert and S. Luttrell.<ref name="register Odeon" />
==Earthquake damage== The building was severely damaged in the February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]]. Demolition was ordered by the [[Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority]] in January 2012.<ref>{{cite news |last=Heather |first=Ben |title=More Christchurch buildings marked for demolition |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/rebuilding-christchurch/6248855/More-Christchurch-buildings-marked-for-demolition |accessdate=18 September 2012 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=12 January 2012}}</ref> In September of that year, the rear of the building was demolished.<ref>See photos in Commons category</ref> The front of the building is protected by a stack of shipping containers placed in Tuam Street; it is hoped to retain at least the façade of the building, but its future is uncertain; this is still the case as of September 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Powerless to stop heritage demolition |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/8014704/Powerless-to-stop-heritage-demolition |accessdate=7 February 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=29 November 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{commons category|Odeon Theatre, Christchurch}} {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Christchurch earthquakes}}

page.title: Over the River...Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=September 2017}} {{notability|Films|date=September 2017}} {{unreferenced|date=September 2017}} }} {{Infobox film | name = Over the River…Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom | image = | caption = | director = [[Constance Jackson|Constance L. Jackson]] | starring = James M. Black
Michele Patterson
Greta Muxworthy
Beth Lockhart
Jacob Conrad | music = | cinematography = | editing = Christopher L. Rowland | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2007|11|17}} | runtime = 140 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Over the River…Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom''''' is a 2007 [[documentary film]] and book about the life of [[Lydia Maria Child]]. The film was produced by Permanent Productions, Inc., written and directed by [[Constance Jackson|Constance L. Jackson]], narrated by [[Diahann Carroll]] and features James Moses Black, Michele S. Patterson, Greta Muxworthy, Beth Lockhart and Jacob Conrad. ==Background== Before the [[Civil Rights Movement#Civil rights movement in the United States|Civil Rights Movement]] of the 1950s and 1960s and before the names of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.|Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr.]] and [[Rosa Parks]] were uttered as harbingers of [[social justice]], came the first Civil Rights Movement in America—the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionists]] of the 19th century. Abolitionists used literature, petitions, and public speaking to forge change, but there was one who stood out in her time that was central to altering America's course: the author and editor, Lydia Maria (pronounced Mariah) Child. Many would argue that Lydia Maria Child and the abolitionist cause were one of the key reasons the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] happened. Coined by [[William Lloyd Garrison]] as the "First Woman in the Republic," Child was an unwavering advocate for change. Child's influence extended to legislators and to President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. A friend and loyalist to [[African Americans]], [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], and [[immigrant]] causes, Child's literature, that span 50 years, made her a household name in thousands of homes during those tumultuous times in America. She is known today as the author of the [[Thanksgiving|Thanksgiving Day]] song ''[[Over the River and Through the Woods|Over the River and Through the Woods to Grandmother's House We Go]]''. Her many books were the first written on the subjects of religious ideas, aging, interracial love, domestic advice, [[Native Americans in the United States|Indian]] rights, [[women's rights]], prison and [[Social movement|social reform]], and abolishing slavery. The bombshell book written in 1833 ''[[An Appeal in Favor of that Class of Americans Called Africans]]'' transcended time and was used by leaders during the 1960s Civil Rights Movement. Many of her books are housed in museums or used as reference material in libraries, while some of her works are still published today for lay readers, scholars, and researchers studying the impact she made on Americans. Lydia Maria Child was well regarded and quite known as an influential figure among her abolitionist and literary peers. ''Over the River'' highlights the relationship Child had with notable figures such as [[William Lloyd Garrison]], [[Theodore Parker]], [[Thomas Wentworth Higginson]], [[Abby Kelley]], [[Frederick Douglass]], [[Lucretia Mott]], [[Maria Weston Chapman]], [[Harriet Jacobs]], Senator [[Charles Sumner]], [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]], [[Grimké sisters|Angelina Grimke]], [[Robert Gould Shaw]], [[Edgar Allan Poe]], [[Margaret Fuller]], violinist [[Ole Bull]], [[John Greenleaf Whittier]], [[James Russell Lowell]], and [[Isaac Hopper|Isaac T. Hopper]], just to name a few. The epic three-part documentary DVD and book ''Over the River...Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom'' explores the life of Lydia Maria Child and the abolitionist soldiers, and displays how young and old, en masse, rallied for social change for all Americans — to free themselves and black Americans from the chains of indignity. ==Writer, director, producer== *Constance L. Jackson ==Cast== *[[Diahann Carroll]], narrator *James Moses Black, David Walker *Michele S. Patterson, Adult Lydia Maria Child *Greta Muxworthy, Young Lydia Maria Child *Beth Lockhart, Young Adult Lydia Maria Child *Jacob Conrad, Religious Critic *Darnell R. Ford, Slave and Preacher ==References== {{Reflist}} *Cox, James A. (April 2009). [http://www.midwestbookreview.com/ibw/apr_09.htm#biog The Bookwatch]. ''The Midwest Book Review'' *Dhondt, Melodie S. (March/April 2009). Rediscover the Amazing Lydia Maria Child. [http://www.njparentweb.com/ ''NJ Parent''] *Baylor, Leroy (March 22, 2009). ''The Communicators'' - Constance L. Jackson Interview. [http://www.whcr.org/ WHCR Radio - the Voice of Harlem] *Gallagher, Karen (February 22, 2009). Life of Child more than Poem. [http://www.news-journalonline.com/ ''The Daytona Beach Journal''] *Best, Bonitta (February 11, 2009). Writer-Turned-Abolitionist-for-Freedom. [http://www.triangletribune.com/ ''The Triangle Tribune''] ==Related events== Director Constance L. Jackson presented ''Over The River'' at Colgate University on October 22, 2009 and lead a workshop discussion titled "Becoming an Agent of Change, Then and Now" (centered around the film ''Over the River...Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom'') on October 23, 2009, where Jackson helped create the definition of an Agent of Change with Colgate University faculty, students, residents, and guests of Hamilton, NY. ==External links== * [http://www.permproductions.com/ Permanent Productions, Inc.] * [http://www.overtherivermovie.com/ ''Over the River…Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom'' (2008) Official Web Site] * [http://www.mediaturbo.com/media/permanentproductions/pp0901.html ''Over the River…Life of Lydia Maria Child, Abolitionist for Freedom'' (2008) Press Release] * {{IMDb title|0361997}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] [[Category:Documentary films about writers]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Documentary films about slavery in the United States]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{underlinked|date=February 2018}}
{{Infobox building | name = Palace of Nakhchivan Khans | native_name={{lang-az|Naxçıvan xanlarının sarayı}} | former_names = | alternate_names = | image = Nakhchivan khan palace7.JPG | caption = | altitude = | building_type =Palace | architectural_style = [[Architectural school of Nakhchivan]] | location = Ajami seyrangah | location_town = [[File:Nakhchivan2.png|22px|]] [[Nakhchivan (city)|Nakhchivan]] | location_country =[[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic]], Azerbaijan | address = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | map_type = Azerbaijan | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = Location within Azerbaijan | coordinates = {{coord|39.205288|N|45.405717|E}} | start_date = | completion_date = XVIII century | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | architect = | other_designers = | references = }} '''Palace of Nakhchivan Khans''' ({{lang-az|Naxçıvan xanlarının sarayı}}) is historical and architectural monument of the 18th century located in [[Nakhchivan (city)|Nakhchivan]]. The monument built in the style of the Nakhchivan-Maragha architectural school was the residence of the Nakhchivan khans before the early 20th century. At the end of the 18th century, the palace was built with the order of Nakhchivan khan, [[Ehsan Khan Nakhichevansky|Ehsan Khan]]’s father Kelbali Khan Kangarli.<ref name="serqqapisi">{{cite web|title= Naxçıvanın Xan sarayı|url= http://www.serqqapisi.az/index.php/humanitar/m-d-niyy-t/2807-nakhdzh-van-n-khan-saray|publisher= serqqapisi.az|language= az|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> The Khan Palace has been operating since April 1998 as Nakhchivan Carpet Museum.
==Design== The Khan Palace is built on the western side of the palace complex with a 3600 m² area, facing daylight as khan steep. The Khan Palace complex features a 42 x 8 m building, a newly built swimming pool, water well, green stripes, ornamental and fruit trees. The building is two floors. By the time the palace consisted of two separate sections. The southern section is intended for administrative work and reception of high-class guests, while the northern section is intended for khan's family. Entrance to sections was one of the corridors with two-storeyed balconies. Currently, only southern corridor is used because of the museum's location in the palace. An internal passage was created between the sections. The corridors go above the main façade. The stairs are surrounded by bricks and are fixed with wooden railings.<ref name="medeniyyet"/>
The total area of the Khan Palace is 382 m² and thickness of its walls vary from 60 cm to 1.1 m. The building was built with baked bricks of 20x20x5 cm. The windows have network styles and all rooms have all sizes of niches Nakhchivan residential houses used. There are 3 rooms on the 1st floor, 8 rooms (2 halls) on 2nd floor and 2 attics on the ornaments that are used as rooms. Both mansions have access to open balconies over the corridors. In the western part of the hall designed for guests, a 40 cm height stage type couch was built. The open windows of the wooden beam are decorated with nets and ceilings with small mirrors. Other walls of the hall have been designed with trunks, fountain and plot illustrations. In the course of many repairs and restoration works, the paintings were damaged or covered with plaster. The southern wall and its surroundings are decorated with geometrical shapes and mirror pieces. The building was warmed by two steamers placed on the walls.<ref name="medeniyyet"/>
==Activity== After the [[Nakhichevan Khanate]] was abolished, the Kangarli cavalry commander was placed in this palace, and the headquarters of the Nakhchivan National Defense Council moved here in 1918–1920. Khan's palace has been preserved in various periods, although it has been preserved.<ref name="medeniyyet">{{cite web|title= Naxçıvan Xan Sarayı|url= http://medeniyyet.az/page/news/12712/Naxcivan-Xan-Sarayi.html|publisher= medeniyyet.az|language= az|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref>
The Khan Palace has been operating since April 1998 as the Nakhchivan Carpet Museum. The museum consists of 8 halls, one of which is dedicated to Nakhchivan khans. At the time of creation 359 exhibits were registered in the museum, but now their number exceeds 2,000 (305 carpets). Here are samples of all types of carpets (xovlu: gaba, zili and xovsuz: sumax, varni, rug, palaz, shadda, cecim, etc.) and carpet products (mufrash, heybat, khurcun, sack, orkan, etc.) is displayed. The carpet samples of the 18th to 19th centuries are stored in the Ganja-Gazakh, Guba-Shirvan, Garabagh, Tabriz-Nakhchivan carpet-weaving schools. According to the flavorings, "Gull Chichi", "Pirabadil", "Alpan", "Ancient Afshan", "Hunting", "Zili", "Old Buta", "Nakhchivan", "Gasimushagi" along with carpets, carved carpets, national carpet (national artist K. Aliyev), "Leyli and Majnun", "Karabakh landscape", "Gray wolves", "Ganja gozal" and others were portrayed by the [[Heydar Aliyev]] also occupies an important place. The museum houses household items – copper samples, pottery and porcelain containers, antique men's and women's national costumes.<ref name="nakhcivan">{{cite web|title= XAN SARAYI – Naxçıvan şəhərində|url= http://www.nakhchivan.az/portal-1/tarixi-abide/xan-sar.htm|publisher= nakhchivan.az|language= az|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> ==Gallery== <center><gallery> File:Nakhchivan khan palace2.JPG| File:Nakhchivan khan palace4.JPG| File:Nakhchivan khan palace5.JPG| File:Naxçıvan_xan_sarayı.jpg| </gallery></center>
==See also== {{Portal|Azerbaijan|Architecture}} [[Architecture of Azerbaijan]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
